conclusion: To determine at which moment the two objects are farthest apart, we need to analyze the area under the velocity-time graph for both objects.
The area under the curve represents the displacement of each object.
The vertical axis represents velocity (v). The horizontal axis represents time (t). The curves A and B represent the velocities of Object A and Object B, respectively.
t1, t2, t3, and t4 are specific time points.
At t2, both objects have the same velocity v0.

premise: The displacement of each object at any time is the area under its respective curve from t = 0 to that time.
conclusion: From 0 to t2, Object A has a higher velocity than Object B, so it covers more distance.

premise: At t2, both objects have the same velocity, but Object A has traveled further up to this point.
conclusion: After t2, Object B's velocity increases and surpasses Object A's velocity.

premise: The maximum separation occurs when the difference in the areas under the curves is the greatest.
conclusion: Before t2, Object A is ahead.

premise: After t2, Object B starts to catch up.
conclusion: The separation is greatest at t2 because beyond this point, Object B begins to reduce the distance between them.

premise: The separation is greatest at t2 because beyond this point, Object B begins to reduce the distance between them.
conclusion: The two objects are farthest apart at time t2.
